**"Raving mad" (v. 23)**: *Mainesthe* suggests the frenzy of the Dionysian cults or other ecstatic pagan religions familiar to the Corinthians. Paul is warning that without order, they look like the very cults they left.

**"Evaluate" (v. 29)**: *Diakrinetōsan* implies a careful weighing or discerning. Prophecy was not to be accepted uncritically; the community was responsible for testing the message.

**"Under the control of" (v. 32)**: The Greek *hypotassetai* (to be subject to) here indicates that prophetic inspiration does not result in a loss of self-control. Unlike the pagan oracles, the Christian prophet remains a responsible agent.

**"Ignored" (v. 38)**: There is a textual variant here (*agnoeito* vs. *agnoeitai*). Following the SBLGNT (*agnoeitai*, "he is ignored/unknown"), it suggests that if a person refuses to recognize Paul's authority, God (or the community) does not recognize that person's standing.

verses.text: Now I am bringing back to your attention, brothers and sisters, the Good News that I announced to you, which you also received, in which you have taken your stand,
and through which you are being saved—provided you hold fast to the message I announced to you, unless your act of faith was for nothing.
For I handed down to you as of first importance what I also received: that Christ died for our sins in accordance with the Scriptures;
and that he was buried; and that he was raised on the third day in accordance with the Scriptures;
and that he appeared to Cephas, then to the Twelve.
After that, he appeared to more than five hundred brothers and sisters at one time, most of whom remain with us until now, though some have fallen asleep.
After that, he appeared to James, then to all the apostles.
Last of all, as though to a freakish, late-term birth, he appeared even to me.
For I am the least of the apostles, unfit even to be called an apostle because I persecuted the church of God.
But by the grace of God I am what I am, and his grace toward me did not prove empty. On the contrary, I labored harder than all of them—though it was not I, but the grace of God that was with me.
So whether it was I or they, this is what we proclaim, and this is what you believed.
Now if it is proclaimed that Christ has been raised from the dead, how can some among you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?
If there is no resurrection of the dead, then not even Christ has been raised.
And if Christ has not been raised, then our proclamation is a hollow shell, and your faith is a hollow shell as well.
More than that, we are found to be false witnesses about God, because we testified against God that he raised the Christ—whom he did not raise, if in fact the dead are not raised.
For if the dead are not raised, not even Christ has been raised.
And if Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile; you are still in your sins.
Then those also who have fallen asleep in Christ have simply perished.
If it is only for this life that we have centered our hope in Christ, we are of all people most to be pitied.
But the fact is, Christ has been raised from the dead, the first-fruits of those who have fallen asleep.
For since death came through a human being, the resurrection of the dead also came through a human being.
For just as in Adam all die, so also in the Christ all will be made alive.
But each in his own proper order: Christ the first-fruits, then those who belong to Christ at his arrival.
Then comes the completion, when he hands over the Kingdom to his God and Father, after he has neutralized every ruler and every authority and power.
For he must reign as king until he has put all his enemies under his feet.
The last enemy to be neutralized is death.
For "he has subjected all things under his feet." Now when it says that "all things" have been subjected, it is obvious that this excludes the One who subjected all things to him.
And when all things are subjected to him, then the Son himself will be subjected to the One who subjected all things to him, so that God may be all in all.
Otherwise, what will those do who are being baptized on behalf of the dead? If the dead are not raised at all, why are people baptized on their behalf?
And why do we put ourselves in danger every hour?
Every day I face death—I swear it by the pride I take in you, brothers and sisters, which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord.
If I fought "wild beasts" in Ephesus from a merely human perspective, what do I gain? If the dead are not raised, "Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die."
Do not be deceived: "Bad company corrupts good character."
Wake up to a sober, righteous mind and stop sinning; for some have no knowledge of God. I say this to your shame.
But someone will ask, "How are the dead raised? With what kind of body do they come?"
You fool! What you sow does not come to life unless it dies.
And what you sow is not the body that is going to be, but a bare grain—of wheat, perhaps, or something else.
But God gives it a body just as he intended, and to each kind of seed a body of its own.
Not all flesh is the same: there is one kind for humans, another for animals, another for birds, and another for fish.
There are also heavenly bodies and earthly bodies; but the glory of the heavenly is one thing, and the glory of the earthly is another.
There is one glory of the sun, another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars; for star differs from star in glory.
So it is with the resurrection of the dead. It is sown in a state of decay, it is raised in a state of imperishability.
It is sown in dishonor, it is raised in glory. It is sown in weakness, it is raised in power.
It is sown a soul-animated body, it is raised a Spirit-animated body. If there is a soul-animated body, there is also a Spirit-animated body.
So it is written: "The first man, Adam, became a living soul"; the last Adam became a life-giving spirit.
But the Spirit-animated is not first; rather, the soul-animated is first, and then the Spirit-animated.
The first man is from the earth, made of dust; the second man is from heaven.
As was the man of dust, so are those who are made of dust; and as is the man of heaven, so are those who are of heaven.
And just as we have worn the image of the man of dust, we will also wear the image of the man of heaven.
I tell you this, brothers and sisters: flesh and blood cannot inherit the Kingdom of God, nor does decay inherit imperishability.
Look, I am telling you a sacred secret: We will not all fall asleep, but we will all be changed,
in an instant, in the blink of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will be raised imperishable, and we will be changed.
For this perishable nature must clothe itself with imperishability, and this mortal nature must clothe itself with immortality.

When this perishable nature clothes itself with imperishability, and this mortal nature clothes itself with immortality, then the word that is written will come true: "Death has been swallowed up in victory."
"Where, O Death, is your victory? Where, O Death, is your sting?"
The sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the law.
But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ!
Therefore, my beloved brothers and sisters, be steadfast, immovable, always excelling in the work of the Lord, because you know that your labor in the Lord is not for nothing.

chapters.notes:
**"Freakish, late-term birth" (v. 8)**: The Greek *ektroma* refers to a miscarriage or an abortion—an untimely or "monstrous" birth. Paul uses this jarring, self-deprecating term to describe his sudden, violent encounter with the risen Christ, which happened outside the "natural" timeframe of the other apostles' experiences.

**"Hollow shell" (v. 14)**: The Greek *kenos* means empty or void of content. Translating it as "hollow shell" captures the idea that the proclamation and faith would be structurally present but lacking any internal substance or reality if the resurrection were false.

**"Futile" (v. 17)**: Unlike *kenos* (empty), *mataia* implies fruitlessness or failing to reach a goal. If Christ is not raised, faith is not just empty; it is ineffective at solving the problem of sin.

**"Neutralized" (v. 24, 26)**: The verb *katargeo* means to render idle, inoperative, or to abolish. In the context of "rulers and authorities," it suggests stripping them of their power and function rather than simple annihilation.

**"Arrival" (v. 23)**: The Greek *parousia* was often used for the formal visit of a royalty or a high official. In the first century, this carried a political and social weight that "coming" fails to convey.

**"Soul-animated body" / "Spirit-animated body" (v. 44)**: This is the most critical technical distinction in the chapter. The Greek *soma psychikon* (traditionally "natural body") and *soma pneumatikon* (traditionally "spiritual body") do not refer to the *material* the body is made of (as if one is meat and the other is ghost-stuff). Rather, they refer to the *power* that animates the body. The *psychikon* body is animated by the *psyche* (the natural life-principle of this age); the *pneumatikon* body is animated by the *Pneuma* (the Holy Spirit/the life-principle of the age to come).

**"Man of dust" (v. 47-49)**: The Greek *choïkos* refers specifically to "loose earth" or "dust," directly alluding to the Septuagint’s description of Adam’s creation in Genesis 2:7.

**"Sacred secret" (v. 51)**: The Greek *mysterion* is not a "mystery" in the sense of a puzzle to be solved, but a divine secret that remained hidden until God chose to reveal it.

**"In an instant" (v. 52)**: The Greek *en atomo* refers to a unit of time so small it cannot be divided (the root of the word "atom"). "In a moment" is common, but "instant" or "atom of time" captures the indivisibility.

verses.text: Now concerning the collection of money for the holy people of God: you should follow the same directions I gave to the churches in Galatia.

On the first day of every week, each of you should set something aside privately, storing up whatever you have gained through your prosperity, so that no collections have to be made only when I arrive.
And when I come, I will send those whom you have approved by your letters of recommendation to carry your gift of grace to Jerusalem.
If it seems appropriate for me to go as well, they will travel with me.
I will come to you after I pass through Macedonia—for I am indeed traveling through Macedonia—
and I may perhaps stay with you, or even spend the winter, so that you yourselves may send me on my way to wherever I go next.
For I do not want to see you now just in passing; I hope to remain with you for some time, if the Lord permits.
But I will remain in Ephesus until Pentecost,
for a great and effective door for ministry has opened for me, and there are many who stand against it.
If Timothy comes, see to it that he has nothing to fear while he is among you, for he is doing the work of the Lord just as I am.
Therefore, let no one treat him with contempt. Send him on his way in peace so that he may come to me, for I am expecting him along with the other brothers.
Now concerning our brother Apollos: I strongly urged him to come to you with the brothers, but it was not at all his will to come now; however, he will come when he has the right opportunity.
Be alert, stand firm in the faith, act with courageous strength, be powerful.
Let everything you do be done in love.
Now I urge you, brothers and sisters—you know that the household of Stephanas were the firstfruits of Achaia, and that they have devoted themselves to the service of the holy people—
I urge you to submit yourselves to such people, and to everyone who joins in the work and labors hard.
I rejoice at the arrival of Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus, because they have filled the void left by your absence.
They have refreshed my spirit and yours. Therefore, give full recognition to such people.
The churches of Asia send you greetings. Aquila and Prisca, together with the church that meets in their house, send you many greetings in the Lord.
All the brothers and sisters here send you greetings. Greet one another with a holy kiss.
This greeting is in my own hand—Paul’s.
If anyone has no love for the Lord, let that person be accursed. *Maranatha*!
The grace of the Lord Jesus be with you.
My love be with all of you in Christ Jesus.

chapters.notes:
**"Holy people" (v. 1, 15)**: The Greek *hagioi* (traditionally "saints") refers to those set apart for God. In this context, it specifically designates the impoverished believers in the Jerusalem church for whom Paul is organizing a relief fund.

**"Gift of grace" (v. 3)**: The Greek *charis* is often translated simply as "gift" or "grace." However, Paul uses it here to describe the monetary collection. It emphasizes that the money is a concrete expression of the grace they have received and are now extending to others.

**"Effective door" (v. 9)**: The Greek *energēs* (from which we get "energetic") suggests something active and at work. The "door" is not just a passive opening, but an active opportunity for Gospel labor.

**"Act with courageous strength" (v. 13)**: The Greek *andrizesthe* literally means "act like a man." In the Greco-Roman context, this was a standard idiom for courage and bravery (virtue/manliness). "Act with courageous strength" captures the behavioral expectation without the modern baggage of the literal gendered idiom.

**"Firstfruits" (v. 15)**: The Greek *aparchē* is a technical term from the Septuagint referring to the first portion of a harvest dedicated to God. To the original audience, it signaled that Stephanas’s family was the beginning of a larger "harvest" of believers in that region.

**"Filled the void left by your absence" (v. 17)**: The Greek *to hymeteron hysterēma* literally means "your deficiency" or "what was lacking from you." Paul is not insulting the Corinthians; he is using a common idiom to say that since the whole Corinthian church could not be with him, these three men served as their representatives, making Paul feel as though the whole church were present.

**"Accursed" (v. 22)**: The Greek *anathema* refers to something handed over or devoted to divine judgment or destruction.

**"Maranatha" (v. 22)**: This is a transliterated Aramaic phrase (*māranā’ thā’*). It was likely a liturgical watchword in the early church, meaning "Our Lord, come!" or "The Lord has come." Given the context of the final greeting, it serves as a prayer for the Second Coming.
